title: Fruit juice and even DIET drinks can increase the risk of deadly diabetes, shock study finds
text:
Drinking diet drinks and fruit juice can increase the risk of developing type 2 diabetes, a new study has found.

Research has found that people who guzzle drink diet drinks, such as Diet Coke, were 18 per cent more likely to develop the condition.

And the shocking results found that drinking just three-and-a-half extra glasses of orange juice a week can raise the risk by 15 per cent.

Research from Harvard University has found that people who guzzle drink diet drinks, such as Diet Coke, (pictured) were 18 per cent more likely to develop type 2 diabetes (file image)

However those who who opt for tea, coffee and water can see their likelihood decrease by ten per cent.

The discovery was made by experts at Harvard University after following nearly 200,000 adults for up to 26 years.

According to the study published in the Diabetes Care journal, the consumption of 'sugary beverages' were associated with the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.

Shocking results found that drinking just three-and-a-half extra glasses of orange juice (pictured) a week can raise the risk by 15 per cent (file image)

Lead researcher Jean-Philippe Drouin-Chartier said: 'The study provides further evidence demonstrating the health benefits associated with decreasing sugary beverage consumption and replacing these drinks with healthier alternatives like water, coffee, or tea,' according to The Daily Star.

However experts believed the increased risk may be associated with people switching to low-calorie drinks because they were already overweight and were already diabetic or at high risk.

'This is a stark reminder that fruit juices are not always the best choice for our morning drink,' Douglas Twenefour, Deputy Head of Care at Diabetes UK said.

Mr Twenefour said Diabetes UK urges people to choose water or unsweetened tea and coffee at breakfast to cut back on sugar intake.

Yet Gavin Partington, Director General at British Soft Drinks Association, said the study does not prove a relationship between diabetes and consuming soft drinks.

Mr Partington said: 'Deterring people from consuming a small 150ml portion of pure fruit juice – which counts as one of your 5 A Day – risks people foregoing the vitamin and phytonutrient benefits of fruit juice.'

Figures show 3.8 million people live with diabetes in the UK and a staggering 90 per cent of those cases are type 2.

Type 2 diabetes is when the body loses its ability to process sugar leading to a high level of blood glucose which can over time damage vital organs.

Being overweight, eating an unhealthy diet and physical inactivity all contribute to developing the condition.
description: Research from Harvard University has found that people who guzzle drink diet drinks, such as Diet Coke, were 18 per cent more likely to develop type 2 diabetes than those who opted for tea and coffee.
